newsitem.title: SINGAPORE: Caltex plans $5 billion on global investments.
newsitem.headline: Caltex plans $5 billion on global investments.

text.p: Caltex Petroleum Corp, a joint venture of U.S. oil majors Texaco Inc and Chevron Corp, plans to spend up to $5 billion on global investments by 2000, Chairman David Law-Smith said on Monday.
The chairman was speaking in Singapore at a press conference to unveil a $500 million programme to support a new brand for the company.

"This is part of an overall investment objective in which Caltex plans to spend up to $5 billion through to the end of the decade on suitably attractive investment projects," Law-Smith told reporters.
He did not immediately detail any investment plans.
The new brand will include a redesign of the Caltex service stations and convenience stores along with a new logo.
It will be rolled out country by country starting in south-east Asia, he said.
Caltex is a refiner of petroleum products in 60 countries and territories in Asia-Pacific, Africa and the Middle East.
In 1995 the company's revenues were $15 billion.
